bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, August 6, 1952

div1.p: Hench appreciates Cornelia Kean's approval of his efforts to memorialize the people involved with the yellow fever work in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, August 6, 1952
div1.opener:
August 6, 1952
Mrs. J. R. Kean
2804 N Street N.W.
Georgetown
Washington 7, D.C.
My dear Mrs. Kean:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your gracious reply of
August 4 and for your general approval of my
efforts.

I shall send General Love today copies of the
material that I sent to Colonel Siler. I should
have done that. It just slipped my mind.
By the way, I suggested to Doctor Nogueira that
his committee very seriously consider placing
the names of General Leonard Wood and General
Kean also on the bronze tablet; however as you
well know, it is awfully hard to get the Cubans
to take suggestions and I have no idea what they
will do.

Yesterday I sent a cable to Doctor Nogueira asking
him to answer my last two letters. If I don't hear
or if his answer is not satisfactory, I think I
will put the matter before several people in
Havana, perhaps also the Surgeon General. I
shall keep you informed.

I will not use your note publicly. I am very
glad to have it and may use it privately and
I am happy indeed to have your general approval.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
